Fig. 2 XRD patterns (a), XPS full-spectra (b), corresponding decomposed N 1s high resolution XPS spectra (c), and relative contents of N bond configurations (d) of N-doped CS, NCS-500, NCS-600, NCS-700, and NCS-800. (AC in legend of (a) stands for amorphous carbon). Fig. 3 SEM images and corresponding size distribution histograms of N-doped CS (a, b) and NCS-600 (c, d). Fig. 4 SEM image (a), XRD pattern (b), HRTEM image and corresponding FFT pattern (c), TEM images (d–g), HAADF-STEM image, and EDX elemental maps for C, N, O, and Pt elements (h) of Pt/NCS composites. Fig. 5 XPS full-spectrum (a), decomposed high resolution XPS spectra of C 1s (b), N 1s (c), and Pt 4f (d) for Pt/NCS composites. Fig. 6 XPS full spectra (a), decomposed high resolution XPS spectra of Pt 4f (b), and corresponding relative contents of Pt species (c) for Pt/NCS electrodes in various charge-discharge states. Fig. 7 CV curves at various scanning rates and corresponding CV peak currents versus square root of scanning rates for NCS electrode (a, c) and Pt/NCS electrode (b, d). Fig. 8 CV curves of NCS/S and Pt/NCS/S electrodes measured at 0.1 mV s−1 (a); corresponding Tafel plots calculated from oxidation peak at 2.40 V (b) and reduction peak at 2.00 V (c); Nyquist plots of Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S electrodes before cycling and after 10 cycles and equivalent circuit (d); chronoamperometry curves of Li2S8/tetraglyme solution discharged at 2.05 V on Pt/NCS and NCS electrodes (e); CV curves of Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S symmetric cells with Li2S6 electrolyte at 20 mV s−1 (f). Fig. 9 Galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of Pt/NCS/S (a) and NCS/S electrodes (b) at various current densities; the potential gaps between discharge and charge plateaus for Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S electrodes (c); rate performances (d) and cycling performances (e) of Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S electrodes; cycling performance of Pt/NCS/S electrode with high S mass loading of 4.4 mg cm−2 at 0.2 C (f). Fig. 10 Schematic illustration of bi-directional catalytic conversion processes for active Pt species (a); in-situ Raman spectra and corresponding potential-time curves for Pt/NCS/S (b, c) and NCS/S (d, e) electrodes. The shuttle effect derived from diffusion of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and sluggish redox kinetic bring about poor cycling stability and low utilization of sulfur, which have always been the key challenging issues for the commercial application of lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries. Rational design of cathode materials to catalyze Li2S dissociation/nucleation processes is an appealing and valid strategy to develop high-energy practical Li-S batteries. Herein, considering the synergistic effect of bidirectional catalysis on LiPSs conversion and enhanced chemical immobilization for LiPSs by heteroatom doping, Pt nanoparticles loaded on nitrogen-doped carbon spheres (Pt/NCS composites) were constructed as cathode materials. According to the dynamic evolution of Pt catalysts and sulfur species, Pt0 and Pt2+ species were identified as active species for the accelerated dissociation and nucleation of Li2S, respectively. Meanwhile, in-situ Raman results demonstrated the expedited conversion of sulfur species resulted from bidirectional catalysis of active Pt species, corresponding to boosted redox kinetics. Consequently, Pt/NCS cathode exhibited improved long-term cyclability with high initial capacity, along with enhanced rate capability. This work provides a facile approach to construct cathode materials with bidirectional catalysis on Li2S dissociation/nucleation, and sheds light on a more global understanding of the catalytic mechanism of metal catalysts during LiPSs conversion. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Platinum species N-doped carbon spheres Bidirectional catalysis Polysulfide conversion 1 Introduction With the rapid growth of electronic vehicles, portable electronic equipments (such as cellular phone, laptop computer, and camcorder), and energy storage devices, new requirements have been put forward on energy storage systems with high energy density, long cycle life, and low cost, which means challenges as well as opportunities [1,2]. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery has been considered as a competitive and promising energy storage system, which possesses high theoretical capacity of 1675 mA h g−1 and ultrahigh energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1 [3]. Besides, sulfur element is environmental friendly and abundant in resource, and endows Li-S batteries with low cost. However, the industrialization process of Li-S batteries is hindered by several inevitable obstacles, such as intrinsic insulating nature of sulfur, solid-phase discharge products (Li2S and Li2S2), volume change of active materials during discharge/charge process, and serious shuttle effect of intermediate lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) [4]. These obstacles would result in hindrance of electron and ion transportation, sluggish redox kinetics, low sulfur utilization, rapid capacity decay, and poor cycling performance, which also obstruct the industrialization process of Li-S batteries [5]. Significantly, shuttle effect is derived from the diffusion of LiPSs to lithium anode and the deposition of LiPSs on anode surface, which has always been the key challenging issue associated with massive loss of active material sulfur and slow sulfur redox reactions [6–8]. Numerous research efforts have been devoted to addressing these obstacles mentioned above [9–11], including employing porous sulfur hosts [12,13], fabricating functional interlayers with lithiophilicity and sulfiphilicity [14–18], modification of electrolytes [19–21], protection of lithium metal anodes [22–24], and especially designing rational catalytic cathode materials [25–35]. Optimization and development of sulfur hosts are essential for the construction of composite cathode materials. Among various sulfur hosts applied in Li-S batteries (carbon-based materials, metal compounds, polymers, and so on), carbon materials are representative due to large specific surface area and good conductivity [36]. However, the weak physical interaction between polar LiPSs and nonpolar carbon materials cannot provide adequate immobilization capacity for LiPSs, and thus the dissolution of LiPSs and shuttle effect still persist. The strategy of heteroatom doping, including nitrogen (N), oxygen (O), sulfur (S), phosphorus (P), and boron (B) elements, could fundamentally regulate the electronic structure and polarity of carbon materials [36,37], endowing carbon materials with enhanced chemical immobilization for LiPSs and electrocatalytic activity to accelerate sulfur redox kinetics [38–42]. Recent research found that pyridinic N configuration could significantly decrease the energy barrier for Li2S decomposition and exhibit the highest binding energy with LiPSs among N-doped configurations (graphitic N, pyrrolic N, and pyridinic N) [38,39]. However, heteroatom doping with high content would be detrimental to electron conductivity of carbon materials [36,43]. Therefore, it is extremely crucial to balance LiPSs immobilization originating from abundant N-doped configurations and conductivity affected by doping content. The incorporation of catalytic materials and modified sulfur hosts as cathodes is proven to be an effective route to increase sulfur utilization and alleviate shuttle effect for Li-S batteries [36,44]. Among representative catalytic materials, transition metal compounds (TMCs) have attracted much research attention due to their strong chemical interactions with LiPSs stemming from polar surfaces [3,45]. Despite making these conspicuous researches progress, TMCs as catalytic materials still suffer from low conductivity, poor charge transfer, limited immobilization capacity, and obscure catalytic mechanism. Recently, we have successfully synthesized metal nanoparticles (NPs) supported catalytic electrode materials, demonstrating that metal NPs catalysts are promising candidates in consideration of rapid electron transfer, excellent electrical conductivity, regulation of Li2S nucleation barrier, and accelerated conversion of LiPSs [46–48]. As Li-S reactions involve bidirectional “sulfur-LiPSs-Li2S” and “Li2S-LiPSs-sulfur” complex changes, unidirectional catalyst is challenging for regulating multistep sulfur redox reactions. Thereby, rational designs of bidirectional catalysts and microstructure of electrodes are strongly desired, along with in-depth understanding of catalytic mechanism and practical applications of high-energy-density pouch cells [45,49–54]. In this work, based on the synergy strategy of bidirectional catalysis on LiPSs conversion integrated with modified sulfur host by heteroatom doping, we successfully constructed Pt NPs loaded on nitrogen-doped carbon spheres (Pt/NCS) composites as cathode for Li-S batteries. The pyridinic N configuration could be generated quantitatively by changing synthesis conditions, leading to the strong adsorption to LiPSs. The dynamic variation of active Pt species during the discharge-charge process has been revealed; Pt0 and Pt2+ species could selectively catalyze Li2S dissociation and Li2S nucleation processes, resulting in accelerated sulfur redox kinetics. And the detailed conversion pathway of sulfur species for Pt/NCS electrode has been investigated by in-situ Raman, validating the bidirectional catalysis on LiPSs conversion from active Pt species. Consequently, Pt/NCS electrode displays significantly improved long-term cyclability with high initial capacity, enhanced rate capability, and high coulombic efficiency (CE) with high sulfur loading. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of nitrogen-doped carbon spheres (NCS) The typical synthesis of nitrogen-doped carbon spheres could be described as follows. 1.08 g polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was firstly hydrolyzed in 180 mL deionized water at 90 °C for 2 h. Then, 5.6 g melamine and 11 mL formaldehyde were mixed in a beaker at 60 °C for 20 min, leading to the formation of methylolmelamines [55,56]. 2.4 mL acetic acid and above solutions were mixed at 60 °C for 4 min with continuous stirring to obtain nitrogen-doped precursors (designated as N-doped CS), accompanying with purification with deionized (DI) water and alcohol. Finally, nitrogen-doped carbon spheres (NCS) were prepared by pyrolyzing precursors at various temperatures (500, 600, 700, and 800 °C) for 30 min with the heating velocity of 1 °C min−1 in a tube furnace under Ar protection. The as-prepared NCSs were designated as NCS-500, NCS-600, NCS-700, and NCS-800 corresponding to different pyrolysis temperatures. 2.2 Preparation of Pt/NCS composites Firstly, Pt NPs were synthesized by modified polyol method [57]. 50 mL of 0.005 M H2PtCl6 ethylene glycol (EG) solution and 15 mL of 0.5 M NaOH EG solution were mixed and stirred vigorously to obtain homogenous solution, and then the mixed solution was refluxed at 160 °C for 4 h under N2 protection. 0.5 mg mL−1 Pt NPs colloidal solution could be obtained by diluting with appropriate amount EG solution. Afterwards, 20 mL Pt NPs colloidal solution, 0.2 g of NCS powders, and 40 mL ethanol were mixed and stirred intensely, accompanying with sonication. Eventually, Pt/NCS composites could be obtained after vacuum drying at 60 °C overnight. 2.3 Preparation of sulfur cathodes The NCS/S and Pt/NCS/S cathodes were prepared by melt-diffusion method [58]. 30 wt% Pt/NCS composites (or 30 wt% NCS) were mixed with 70 wt% sulfur and ground into homogeneous powders. Then, the mixed powders were heated at 160 °C for 12 h, and the obtained powders were denoted as Pt/NCS/S cathode (or NCS/S cathode). 2.4 Visualized adsorption of lithium polysulfides (Li2S6) Li2S6 solution (3 mmol L−1) was prepared by mixing Li2S and sulfur powders with the molar ratio of 1:5 in 1,3-dioxolane (DOL)/1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (v:v = 1:1) solution. 20 mg NCS and Pt/NCS were added into 6 mL Li2S6 solution, respectively. 2.5 Li-S cell assembly and electrochemical measurements Sulfur electrodes were fabricated by grinding the mixture of Pt/NCS/S composites or NCS/S composites, Super-P, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) with a mass ratio of 7:2:1 and dispersing the mixture into N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The obtained slurry was coated on Al foil and dried in vacuum at 55 °C for 12 h, and then Al foil was cut into 10 mm circular slices as sulfur electrodes. The S mass loading is 1.2 or 4.4 mg cm−2, and the electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio is 10 μL mg−1. CR2032 coin cells were assembled in MBraun glovebox under atmosphere of argon with Celgard 2400 polypropylene (PP) membrance and lithium foil as separator and anode, respectively, in order to conduct electrochemical measurements. The electrolyte is 1.0 M lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide (LiTSFI) in DOL/DME (v:v = 1:1) with 1 wt% LiNO3. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were conducted by a VMP3 (BioLogic) electrochemical workstation. Galvanostatic discharge charge (GCD) tests were characterized on a NEWARE battery testing system (CT-4800). All the electrochemical measurements were performed at room temperature (25 °C). 2.6 Materials characterization The microstructure and morphology characterizations were performed by transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20) and field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, FEI Nova NanoSEM 450). The high angle annular dark-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained by a Fischione Model 3000 HAADF detector (detector half angles between 60 and 210 mrad). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected by a Riguka D/MAX-2400 diffractometer. X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB 250) was conducted to identify electronic state and chemical composition of samples with C 1s calibration at 284.6 eV. The inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was used to acquire the actual Pt loading amount by an ICP-OES instrument (Perkin Elmer Optima 7300 DV). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out by NETZSCH STA 449F5 apparatus from room temperature to 500 °C at heating rate of 5 °C min−1. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis was performed by a micropore physisorption analyzer (TriStar Ⅱ 3020). 2.7 Assembly of Li2S6 symmetric cells The NCS and Pt/NCS powders were mixed with PVDF in NMP solution with the weight ratio of 5:1. Then the obtained homogeneous slurry was coated on circular carbon paper disks with diameter of 10 mm as the counter and working electrodes. Subsequently, two identical electrodes, polypropylene separators, and 40 μL Li2S6 DOL/DME (v:v = 1:1) electrolyte (0.2 mol L−1) were assembled in CR2032 cells. CV measurements of obtained symmetric cells were conducted at scanning rates of 3 and 20 mV s−1 within the potential range of −1 to 1 V. 2.8 Measurements for the lithium sulfide (Li2S) nucleation and decomposition The 0.2 M Li2S8 electrolyte was prepared by intensely mixing lithium sulfide and sulfur powder in tetraglyme with stoichiometric ratio of 1:7. The carbon papers with diameter of 10 mm were used as current collectors to load NCS and Pt/NCS powders as cathodes, and the lithium foils were used as anodes. Li2S nucleation: 20 μL Li2S8 electrolyte (0.2 mol L−1) was added as catholyte and 20 μL electrolyte without Li2S8 was dropped on the lithium anode side. After assembly, the cells were galvanostatically discharged to 2.06 V under the current of 0.112 mA, and discharged potentiostatically at 2.05 V for Li2S nucleation and growth on a VMP3 electrochemical workstation [58,59]. Li2S decomposition: Coin cells were assembled by similar method mentioned in Li2S nucleation part. The cells were galvanostatically discharged to 1.8 V at current of 0.1 mA, and then galvanostatically discharged to 1.7 V under the current of 0.01 mA to promote complete conversion of LiPSs to Li2S. Subsequently, cells were potentiostatically charged at 2.4 V for Li2S dissolution until the current dropped below 0.01 mA. 2.9 In-situ Raman spectroscopy measurement The Raman electrochemical cell was assembled by quartz window, Li foil with a hole, PP separator with smaller hole, and S cathode. The Raman spectra were obtained by a Raman spectroscope (Horiba LabRam HR Evolution) using 532 nm laser. The cell was galvanostatically discharged/charged at current density of 0.1 C during the process of in-situ measurement, and the Raman spectra were acquired every 10 min at discharge-charge cycling. 3 Results and discussion The Pt/NCS composites were prepared via a facile three-step process of polycondensation, carbonization, and Pt NPs loading, as schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 . Initially, methylolmelamines were formed due to hydroxymethylation of formaldehyde and melamine molecules [55], which can be subsequently polymerized under the catalysis of acetic acid to obtain nitrogen-doped precursors (N-doped CS). As presented in Fig. S1, N-doped CS with uniform distribution and size have been synthesized at 60 °C for 4 min. Afterwards, nitrogen-doped carbon spheres (NCS) were prepared by pyrolyzing N-doped CS at various temperatures under Ar protection. In order to precisely evaluate the amounts of nitrogen-doped configurations, XRD and XPS characterizations on N-doped CS and NCS with various carbonization temperatures have been conducted, as shown in Fig. 2 . For N-doped CS, as precursors, one broad diffraction peak at around 23° could be assigned to the amorphous carbon (Fig. 2a). After carbonization, all four NCS samples show two diffraction peaks at 26° and 43.7°, corresponding to the coexistence of nanocrystalline graphite (JCPDS 26-1079) and amorphous carbon [46,60]. The additional diffraction peak located at 37.8° could be found for NCS-800, which corresponds to cubie phase of γ-C3N4 [61,62], indicating that impure phase appears under high temperature condition. In order to investigate the variations of valence states and bond configurations, XPS characterizations on N-doped CS, NCS-500, NCS-600, NCS-700, and NCS-800 have been performed. XPS full-spectra of all five samples display C, N, and O element signals (Fig. 2b), and corresponding decomposed N 1s and C 1s high resolution spectra are plotted in Fig. 2(c) and Fig. S2(b), respectively. The N 1s peak could be deconvoluted into three individual peaks, which are attributed to pyridinic N (398.5 eV), pyrrolic N (399.4 eV), and graphitic N (400.9 eV) bond configurations [56,63,64]. Meanwhile, the C 1s spectra can be divided into four affiliated peaks at 284.6, 285.4, 287.2, and 289.0 eV, belonging to CC, CN, CN, and CO functional groups [63–65]. The relative contents of various N-doped configurations are presented in Fig. 2(d) and Table S1, and those of functional groups in C 1s high resolution spectra are also listed in Table S2. Obviously, the relative content of graphitic N configuration increases sharply to 73.7% with the pyrolysis temperature elevated to 800 °C. Simultaneously, the relative contents of pyridinic N and pyrrolic N configurations decrease substantially along with the increase of pyrolysis temperature. Besides, it is worth noting that the content of N element in NCS is significantly declined as the temperature ascended (Fig. S2a), accompanied by the decreasing amount of N-doped configurations. The massive researches indicate that N-doped configurations, especially pyridinic N, could moderately regulate the polarity of carbon materials, resulting in the strong adsorption to LiPSs and the enhanced electrocatalytic performance on redox processes of LiPSs conversion [38,39,66]. Therefore, in order to balance the conductivity of carbon matrix (more precisely, the graphitization degree) and the relative content of N-doped configurations, pyrolysis temperature is the key parameter to obtain suitable matrix material. Herein, NCS pyrolyzed at 600 °C (NCS-600) were used as matrix to construct conductive cathode for Li-S batteries. The SEM images and corresponding size distribution histograms of N-doped CS and NCS-600 are displayed in Fig. 3 . Both N-doped CS and NCS-600 exhibit spherical morphology and uniform particle size distribution. The mean size diameter for N-doped CS is 379.9 nm; after the carbonization process, the mean diameter for NCS-600 drops dramatically to 174.6 nm. The distinct decrease in particle size could be attributed to the crystallization process and partial removal of surface functional groups. Herein, Pt nanoparticles (NPs) were initially obtained by modified polyol process with ethylene glycol as reaction medium and reducing agent. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image and size distribution histogram for Pt NPs are shown in Fig. S3. The interplanar spacings of 1.96 and 2.27 Å could be ascribed to Pt (2 0 0) and (1 1 1) planes, and the mean size for NPs is about 2.95 nm. Subsequently, Pt/NCS composites can be obtained by loading Pt NPs on NCS. The SEM image, XRD pattern, HRTEM, and TEM images of Pt/NCS composites are presented in Fig. 4 (a–g). Obviously, the Pt/NCS composites are monodispersed particles with spherical morphology. However, the diffraction peaks of Pt NPs could not be detected by XRD, which is ascribed to the low weight ratio of Pt in Pt/NCS composites (Fig. 4b). From HRTEM image and fast Fourier transform (FFT) pattern (Fig. 4c), NPs with basal spacings of 2.27 and 1.96 Å can be confirmed and indexed as the (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) planes of cubic Pt viewed along (0 1 1) zone axis. Besides, a large number of Pt NPs could be observed clearly in magnified TEM images (Fig. 4d–g), which are distributed uniformly on the surface of NCS matrix. Moreover, the HAADF-STEM image and corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental maps also verify the homogeneous distribution of C, N, and O elements and the well-distributed Pt NPs on NCS surface (Fig. 4h). Meanwhile, the actual Pt loading amount of 0.127 wt% was determined by ICP-OES. Consequently, Pt NPs supported on NCS with uniform distribution and low Pt weight ratio have been successfully synthesized. To preliminarily evaluate the interaction between LiPSs and NCS matrix, visualized adsorption experiments of NCS and Pt/NCS composites in Li2S6 solution have been conducted (Fig. S4). The color for Li2S6 solutions with NCS and Pt/NCS changed from dark yellow to transparent after 72 h, indicating the strong adsorption capability of NCS matrix due to the large number of polar N-doped configurations. The adsorption capacity for Pt/NCS to Li2S6 is slightly inferior to the pure NCS matrix, which could be ascribed to the decreased surface area after Pt NPs loading. BET results (Fig. S5 and Table S3) show abundant pores on the NCS, which provide sufficient space to accommodate LiPSs and hinder the diffusion of LiPSs during cycling process. In addition, according to TGA curves (Fig. S6), the theoretical sulfur loading amount of 70% can be reached for Pt/NCS/S, indicating that most of sulfur can be incorporated into NCS matrix. The electronic structures of Pt/NCS composites have been revealed by XPS characterization, as presented in Fig. 5 . The signals of C, N, O, and Pt elements are confirmed in XPS full-spectrum (Fig. 5a), and decomposed high resolution spectra of C 1s, N 1s, and Pt 4f are shown in Fig. 5(b–d), respectively. As for decomposed Pt 4f high resolution spectrum (Fig. 5d), there exist two obvious characteristic peaks centered at 75.0 and 71.8 eV, corresponding to Pt 4f 5/2 and Pt 4f 7/2 splittings. Each characteristic peak can be decomposed into three individual peaks, which are attributed to Pt0 (metallic state), Pt2+, and Pt4+ (oxidized states) species [46,57,67,68], indicating the coexistence of Pt species with various valence states. It is extremely crucial to detect and comprehend the evolution of composition, valences, and bond structures for electrode materials during the charge-discharge process. XPS characterizations on Pt/NCS electrodes in various charge-discharge states have been conducted in order to more accurately reveal the catalytic effect of Pt NPs. The obtained XPS full spectra, decomposed high resolution spectra of Pt 4f, C 1s, and N 1s are displayed in Fig. 6 (a and b) and Fig. S7(a and b), while the relative contents of Pt species in various charge-discharge states are presented in Fig. 6(c). There exist Pt 4f 5/2 and Pt 4f 7/2 characteristic peaks in Pt 4f spectra in various charge-discharge states (Fig. 6b); each peak can be fitted into three individual peaks corresponding to metallic state (Pt0) and oxidized states (Pt2+ and Pt4+). Most noteworthy, the relative content of Pt in metallic state (Pt0) decreases from 40.7% to 33.5% in the discharge process, and then increases from 32.5% to 44.3% when charging to 2.7 V. Conversely, the relative content of Pt2+ oxidized species shows an upward trend but then a descending trend after charging to 2.5 V. Meanwhile, the content of Pt4+ oxidized species remains almost unchanged (around 11%), and the relevant statistics are listed in Table S4. Consequently, the dynamic content variations of Pt species during the discharge-charge process have been clearly revealed. To be precise, the most notable features are the increasing concentration of Pt2+ oxidized species during discharging process and rising content of Pt0 species during charging process. The Li+ diffusion coefficient is a crucial parameter to evaluate electron and ion transmission efficiencies in Li-S batteries, which are closely associated with diffusion and conversion of LiPSs. Consequently, CV measurements at scanning rates of 0.1 to 0.5 mV s−1 for both NCS and Pt/NCS electrodes were performed (Fig. 7 a and b), and corresponding plots of redox peak current versus square root of scanning rate were linear fitted (Fig. 7c and d). The Li+ diffusion coefficients for anodic peak A (Li2S → S8) and cathodic peaks B (S8 → Li2S n ) and C (Li2S n → Li2S) can be calculated by the following equation, which is deduced from Randles-Sevcik equation [69–71]. (1) I p = 2.69 × 10 5 n 1.5 A D L i + + C L i + 0.5 v 0.5 where n stands for the number of charge transfer, A is 0.785 cm2 (electrode surface area), D Li+ represents Li+ diffusion coefficient, C Li+ refers to Li+ concentration in electrolyte, v is scanning rate, I p refers to redox peak current. The calculated Li+ diffusion coefficients for NCS and Pt/NCS electrodes are listed in Table 1 , and the higher coefficients for Pt/NCS electrode indicate the faster Li+ transport, improving diffusion and conversion of LiPSs. To further demonstrate the effect of Pt species during the catalytic conversion of LiPSs, relevant electrochemical characterizations of Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S electrodes have been carried out on CR2032 coin cells. As displayed in Fig. 8 (a), the CV curves of both electrodes with scanning rate of 0.1 mV s−1 demonstrate the differences in current density and redox peak position. The negative shifts of anode peaks, positive shifts of cathode peaks, and enhanced current density could be observed for Pt/NCS/S electrode. In addition, corresponding Tafel plots calculated from oxidation peaks (around 2.40 V) and reduction peaks (around 2.00 V) are shown in Fig. 8(b and c). As for the reduction process, the Tafel slopes for NCS/S and Pt/NCS/S electrodes are 70.0 and 61.0 mV dec−1, and corresponding exchange current densities are 0.70 and 1.75 mA cm−2, respectively. In the oxidation process, NCS/S electrode demonstrates a Tafel slope of 131.7 mV dec−1 and an exchange current density of 4.10 mA cm−2; by contrast, Pt/NCS/S electrode exhibits a Tafel slope of 63.6 mV dec−1 and an exchange current density of 32.73 mA cm−2. The shifts of redox peaks, lower Tafel slopes, and improved exchange current densities for Pt/NCS/S electrode indicate the increased conversion rates of LiPSs and enhanced redox reaction kinetics [72,73]. Furthermore, EIS measurements of Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S electrodes before cycling and after 10 cycles at 0.2 C were performed (Fig. 8d). Each Nyquist plot contains two semicircles in high frequency range, corresponding to R g (resistance of insulating Li2S layer and solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer on Li anode after cycling) and R ct (charge transfer resistance) [72–74]. Obviously, Pt/NCS/S electrode shows smaller R g and R ct, demonstrating the enhanced charge transfer capability and improved electronic conductivity. The lithium sulfide (Li2S) nucleation measurements on Pt/NCS and NCS cathodes have also been conducted, which are involved with reduction of Li2S8, reduction of Li2S6, and deposition of Li2S [58,75–77]. The obtained chronoamperometry curves of Li2S8/tetraglyme solution discharged at 2.05 V on Pt/NCS and NCS electrodes are presented in Fig. 8(e). Deduced and calculated from Faraday’s law [76], Pt/NCS electrode provides larger Li2S precipitation capacity of 178.5 mA h g−1, compared with that for NCS electrode (124.4 mA h g−1). Simultaneously, Pt/NCS electrode shows a shorter nucleation process (around 2300 s) than NCS electrode (around 30000 s). The higher precipitation capacity and shorter nucleation period for Pt/NCS electrode demonstrate the acceleration of conversion from LiPSs to Li2S. Besides, the larger dissolving capacity of Li2S on Pt/NCS electrode (165.8 mA h g−1) can be deduced (Fig. S8) along with a shorter dissolution process, indicating the promoted dissolution process of Li2S. Thus, the bidirectional catalysis on LiPSs conversion could be verified by Li2S precipitation and decomposition experiments. Moreover, CV measurements for Pt/NCS and NCS symmetric cells with Li2S6 electrolyte at 20 and 3 mV s−1 were carried out (Fig. 8f and Fig. S9). Both CV curves for Pt/NCS electrode at 20 and 3 mV s−1 show higher redox current densities than those for NCS electrode. These electrochemical experiment results verify the accelerated redox kinetics and enhanced catalytic conversion of LiPSs from active Pt species. The rate and cycling performances were also evaluated on coin cells with lithium as anode and Pt/NCS/S, NCS/S as cathodes. The galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S electrodes with varying current densities are displayed in Fig. 9 (a and b). Fig. 9(c) shows the corresponding potential gaps (ΔV) between discharge/charge plateaus for both electrodes. Pt/NCS electrode delivers more stable plateaus and smaller polarization (ΔV) due to enhanced reaction kinetics, corresponding to rapid oxidation process of insoluble Li2S and promoted reduction reaction of liquid-state LiPSs to solid-state Li2S. By comparison, the higher ΔV for NCS electrode would induce the accumulation of insoluble Li2S, resulting in low utilization of active materials and rapid capacity decay [78]. Rate performances and cycling performances for NCS/S and Pt/NCS/S electrodes were measured on assembled coin cells, as presented in Fig. 9(d and e). Pt/NCS/S electrode exhibits enhanced rate performance with specific capacities of 1187.2, 773.6, 624.0, 520.0, 458.0, and 422.6 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2 C. Besides, its specific capacity could recover to 924.4 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C after cycling at current density of 2 C, indicating stable reversibility with capacity retention of 77.9%. In contrast, NCS/S electrode shows relatively weak rate capacities of 854.2, 674.9, 562.3, 474.3, 410.3, and 349.2 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2 C, respectively. Meanwhile, the improved cycling performance for Pt/NCS/S electrode has been verified (Fig. 9e). Pt/NCS/S electrode achieves the maximum capacity of 1063.0 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and retains the reversible capacity of 368.7 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles with negligible decaying rate of 0.130% per cycle. As for NCS/S electrode, it exhibits an initial capacity of 845.1 mA h g−1 and decayed capacity of 217.6 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles. Moreover, in order to reveal the structural and morphological evolutions of Pt NPs catalysts, TEM and EDX characterizations of Pt/NCS electrode after cycling were conducted (Fig. S10). The abundant Pt NPs distributed on the surface of NCS matrix and homogeneous distributions of C, N, O, S, and Pt elements could be observed, which illustrated the stable existence of Pt NPs with reliable performance and the physical confinement from steady diffusion of LiPSs into surface layer of NCS matrix [46]. Additionally, the cycling performance for Pt/NCS/S electrode with high S loading of 4.4 mg cm−2 and lean electrolyte (E/S = 10) has also been evaluated at current density of 0.2 C, as shown in Fig. 9(f). Pt/NCS/S electrode delivers a maximum capacity of 770.7 mA h g−1 and maintains a stable capacity of 556.4 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles with capacity retention of 72.2%. Evidently, the obtained electrochemical results demonstrate that active Pt species would accelerate the nucleation and dissociation of Li2S and the conversion of LiPSs, enhancing redox reaction kinetics. The aforementioned electrochemical performances for Pt/NCS electrode manifest the enhanced redox kinetics for the bidirectional process, more specifically, the conversion from LiPSs to Li2S during discharge process and reaction from Li2S to LiPSs in the charge process. Take into consideration of content variations of Pt species in various charge-discharge states, the increasing amount of Pt2+ oxidized species in discharge process corresponds to promoted Li2S nucleation process; simultaneously, the growing concentration of Pt0 metallic species in charge process is strongly associated with rapid Li2S dissociation process. Consequently, the schematic illustration of bidirectional catalytic conversion processes for active Pt species is presented in Fig. 10 (a). Pt0 and Pt2+ species could selectively catalyze Li2S dissociation and Li2S nucleation processes, leading to accelerated sulfur redox kinetics. In order to reveal the conversion process of sulfur species and verify the catalytic effect of Pt species on the conversion of LiPSs, in-situ Raman spectroscopy measurements for Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S electrodes have been performed by an in-situ Raman cell (cell configuration presented in Fig. S11). The in-situ Raman spectra, potential-time curves, and conversion processes of sulfur species for Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S electrodes are displayed in Fig. 10(b–e); the dots in potential-time curves (Fig. 10c and e) correspond to Raman spectra acquired at specific potentials (Fig. 10b and d). For both Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S electrodes, Raman signals of S8 (150, 219, and 474 cm−1), Li2S6 (176 and 389 cm−1), Li2S4 (202, 235, and 413 cm−1), and Li2S2 (460 cm−1) species can be detected during discharge-charge cycling [59,79–84]. Notably, the peak attributed to Li2S (375 cm−1) has not been observed in spectra for Pt/NCS/S and NCS/S electrodes even when cells were discharged to 1.7 V, which could be ascribed to the incomplete reduction of sulfur to insoluable Li2S during the process of in-situ measurement and the sluggish solid-state diffusion of lithium ions [59,85]. During the discharge process, the signal of S8 for Pt/NCS electrode totally disappears at 2.10 V, earlier than the NCS electrode (2.05 V). Besides, the characteristic peaks for Li2S6, Li2S4, and Li2S2 can be initially identified when discharging at 2.10, 2.05, and 2.05 V for Pt/NCS electrode, while those for NCS electrode were first found at 2.05, 1.85, and 1.85 V. The accelerating conversions of S8 to LiPSs and LiPSs to Li2S2/Li2S demonstrate the reduced energy barriers from active Pt species in discharge process (S8 → Li2S8 → Li2S6 → Li2S4 → Li2S2/Li2S). As for the charge process, the whole conversion process of sulfur species (Li2S2/Li2S → Li2S4 → Li2S6 → Li2S8 → S8) could be clearly observed for Pt/NCS electrode (Fig. 10b). The spectral signals of Li2S2 and Li2S4 gradually vanished when charging to 2.40 V and the increasing spectral peak of S8 can be recognized with charging voltage from 2.40 to 2.70 V. In stark contrast, NCS electrode exhibited the mixture signals of Li2S2, Li2S4, and Li2S6 at the beginning of charging process and the weak signal of S8 at the termination stage of charge procedure (Fig. 10d), indicating that incomplete conversion of sulfur species and sluggish redox kinetics. The in-situ Raman results verify the bidirectional catalytic effect of Pt species, involved with promoted Li2S nucleation and dissociation processes, which guarantees the relatively stable reversibility and electrochemical performance for Pt/NCS electrode. 4 Conclusions In summary, comprehensively considering the adsorption of LiPSs and catalysis on LiPSs conversion, we rationally designed and constructed Pt NPs loaded on nitrogen-doped carbon spheres (Pt/NCS composites) as catalytic cathode material for Li-S batteries. The precise regulation on the content of pyridinic N configuration enhances LiPSs immobilization and ensures the good conductivity of NCS matrix, facilitating the mobility of ions and electrons. Most notably, the active Pt0 and Pt2+ species can selectively catalyze Li2S dissociation and Li2S nucleation processes, leading to accelerated sulfur redox kinetics. The reduced energy barriers of reversible conversions of S8 to LiPSs and LiPSs to Li2S2/Li2S could be verified by the improved electrochemical performances and detailed conversion pathway of sulfur species. Finally, benefiting from bidirectional catalysis from active Pt species and modified sulfur host, Pt/NCS cathode presents improved cycling performance with initial specific capacity of 1063.0 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and maintains the reversible capacity of 368.7 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles, together with upgraded rate performance with high capacity of 1187.2 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C. Collectively, this work demonstrates a reasonable and workable route to construct metal catalysts supported cathode materials that can accelerate Li2S dissociation/nucleation processes, paving the path for application of energy storage system with fast charge-discharge ability and high energy density. coredata.dc:description: The shuttle effect derived from diffusion of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and sluggish redox kinetic bring about poor cycling stability and low utilization of sulfur, which have always been the key challenging issues for the commercial application of lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries. Rational design of cathode materials to catalyze Li2S dissociation/nucleation processes is an appealing and valid strategy to develop high-energy practical Li-S batteries. Herein, considering the synergistic effect of bidirectional catalysis on LiPSs conversion and enhanced chemical immobilization for LiPSs by heteroatom doping, Pt nanoparticles loaded on nitrogen-doped carbon spheres (Pt/NCS composites) were constructed as cathode materials. According to the dynamic evolution of Pt catalysts and sulfur species, Pt0 and Pt2+ species were identified as active species for the accelerated dissociation and nucleation of Li2S, respectively. Meanwhile, in-situ Raman results demonstrated the expedited conversion of sulfur species resulted from bidirectional catalysis of active Pt species, corresponding to boosted redox kinetics. Consequently, Pt/NCS cathode exhibited improved long-term cyclability with high initial capacity, along with enhanced rate capability. This work provides a facile approach to construct cathode materials with bidirectional catalysis on Li2S dissociation/nucleation, and sheds light on a more global understanding of the catalytic mechanism of metal catalysts during LiPSs conversion.
